Description: Large scarab carved from steatite; back well defined with detailed clypeus, and prothorax and elytra marked by incised double and triple lines respectively; triangle on elytra at junction with prothorax on each side; side view unknown; underside incised with motif arranged horizontally consisting of god Bes flanked by monkeys which raise their hands in a worshipping attitude, and by roughly made sun-discs (almost ovals) at his head's level; pierced lengthwise; glaze worn; in yellow-brown steatite.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Scarab Factory (according to museum register)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The depiction of Bes worshipped by two monkeys is well attested on scarabs and scaraboids, Naukratis included. Bes has here a solar aspect, since worshipping monkeys are very often associated with solar symbols such as scarab, obelisk and the cartouche of Menkheperra (Jaeger 1982, 213 § 1393). B. Jaeger lists other occurrences of this design on convex rectangular plaques and scaraboids, most of which can be dated to the Ramesside Period (Jaeger 1982, 218-219 § 1408) and he thinks that the stone scarabs which depicts Bes found in Naukratis should probably be dated to this period too (Jaeger 1982, 205 § 1366, n. 868). However, a scarab in green glazed steatite showing a similar design was discovered in the Third Intermediate Period cemetery at Matmar (Brunton, G. 1948. Matmar, London, pl. LXIII, 108, mainly dated to the 8th-7th c. BC) and another example quoted by Jaeger himself originates from the Kushite cemetery of Sanam (Griffith 1923, pl. XLV, 8). Though Naukratis scarabs could be archaizing copies of Ramesside types, it is possible that they are genuine Ramesside ones (on the various early scarabs from Naukratis see: Masson forthcoming). See Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVIII, no. 149 for a drawing of this scarab. For further parallels see: Hornung and Staehelin 1976, no. 695-696 (scaraboid and scarab in steatite). Brunton, G. 1948.
